title: Bonguk geom
text:
Bonguk geom (<a href="Korean%20language">Korean</a> 본국검 "<a href="%3Awikt%3A%E6%9C%AC%E5%9C%8B">national</a> <a href="%3Awikt%3A%E5%8A%8D">sword</a>", also "singeom" 신검 "Silla sword") in <a href="Joseon%20era">Joseon era</a> <a href="Korean%20martial%20arts">Korean martial arts</a> (17th to 18th centuries) referred both to a type of <a href="Korean%20sword">sword</a> and a style of <a href="Korean%20swordsmanship">swordsmanship</a>.
The term was introduced in the "<a href="Muyesinbo">Muyesinbo</a>" of 1759, and the system was supposedly a creation of <a href="Crown%20Prince%20Sado">Crown Prince Sado</a>. It contrasts with <a href="Jedok%20geom">Jedok geom</a>, or "admiral sword", a system supposedly introduced by the Chinese admiral <a href="Li%20Rusong">Li Rusong</a> during the 16th-century <a href="Imjin%20War">Imjin War</a> (the "national sword" system is conspicuously absent from the older "<a href="Muyejebo">Muyejebo</a>" manual of 1610).
The "Muyesinbo" stresses the antiquity of this "national" Korean system by including the narrative of a Silla "<a href="Hwarang">Flower Youth</a>" called "Hwangchang", who killed <a href="Baekje">Baekje</a>'s king while performing a <a href="sword%20dance">sword dance</a>, known as <a href="Geommu">Geommu</a>, at the court. 
The historical swords of the Silla period would have been double-edged and comparable to those of the <a href="Eastern%20Han">Eastern Han</a> dynastic period (see also <a href="Hwandudaedo">Hwandudaedo</a>). However, the Bonguk geom, as presented in the 18th-century manual, is historically based on a single-edged sword; a type common during that era.
In contemporary schools of <a href="Korean%20swordsmanship">Korean swordsmanship</a>, the term "bonguk geom" is used to emphasize their "national" Korean character, without necessarily bearing a direct relation to the 18th-century system.
